title: Am I allowed to publish a book that's out of print? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Out of print” isn’t the relevant part; “out of copyright” is. If it’s out of copyright (also called “in the public domain”) then anyone who wants to can publish it, whether it’s in print or not. You are absolutely free to put out your own edition of the Bible, or Dickens’ A Christmas Carol, or Shakespeare’s plays. In the U.S., anything originally published more than 95 years ago — that is, before 1924 — is in the public domain. In most countries it’s not a specific year, it’s whether the author has been dead for seventy years. But whether it’s in print has nothing to do with it. If it’s still under copyright, you need permission from the copyright owner (which is usually the author).

Emphatically not. Whether or not a book is currently available for sale from its publisher has no bearing whatsover on the issue of copyright, which is to say the right to make something available. Laws do vary a bit from country to country, but there’s a decades-long period during which the author (or some other entity) holds the copyright. This is an exclusive right to publish a work, and it doesn’t go away for a very long time. And the only thing that makes it go away is time (there’s a gray area for things which authors deliberately release into the public domain or for which there are “creative commons” and similar licenses, but they’re exceptions where someone is deliberately making them free for all). A publisher is allowed to let a book fall out of print and republish it a while later for business reasons, or simply on a whim. But it’s their right to control publication of the work during the duration of copyright. You don’t get to take that away.

Does it belong to you? Do you have the rights back? It’s not wise to publish someone else’s work, even if it’s in public domain or you think it is. Often major companies, publishing houses, or descendants have those rights. If something appears in public domain, pay a copyright lawyer or the copyright office to do a search before you even consider publishing someone else’s work. If you have your own work and those rights back from the publisher, publish away.

response.answer_text: Ethically not. You have to also consider copyright, and whether it expired. If the work is now in public domain, yes, you could publish it, but you still have to give credit to the original author/illustrator, et cetera.

response.answer_text: Not if it’s still under copyright. If it’s public domain, you can publish it no matter if it’s in print or out, but OOP doesn’t mean it’s not copyrighted.
